msDesc.head: Homiliary (Paul the Deacon, etc.); Germany, mid-12th century

msItem.note: An originally blank page, with numerous later inscriptions, some in German, several erased:
‘Item hic fuit xiij So[ … ](?) | Salve regina misericordie vita | dulcedo et spes mea’ (upper middle)
‘[ … ] vigilate quia aduersarius | noster diabolus tamquam | leo rugiens circuit querens cui resistite fortes | in fide [ … ] domini | nostri’ [cf. I Peter 5:8–9] (upper right corner)

‘Salve regina misericordie vita dulcedo et spes nostra | … | … O clemens. O pia. O dulcis Maria’ (upper middle); the opening words repeated a few times elsewhere on the page (Chevalier 18150; cf. 18147); Analecta hymnica, L (1907), p. 318 no. 245)

‘Quando incipitur a capite lectio sancti evangelii secundum Iohannem. In illo tempore. Dixit Ihesus discipulis suis Vado ad eum qui me misit et nemo ex vobis interrogat me [John 16:5] Omelia venerabilis Bede presbiteri. De eadem lectione. Quando legitur ex omelia … et nemo ex vobis interrogat me quo vadis et reliqua’ (lower left)

Short pen trials include:
‘Homo quid’, repeated several times
‘In omni tribulatione et angustia nostra mart’ …’
‘Caseus est carus dixit quidam avarus | Non sdetur nisi in festis celebretur’ and variants (cf. Walther, Proverbia, no. 2433)
‘Omnia que tua sunt post mortem nil prosunt’ (Walther, Proverbia, no. 20051)

Passages apparently in German include:
‘Con apt zu selgistat | Item hic fuit her joh..(?) .. | prior in selgestat | bruk(?) swalbach reddehern | husescem swalbach gorlach | [ ]hart lut’n herkehusen | dadelsem (upper middle; perhaps Konrad II abbot of Seligenstadt c.1269-79)
‘[…]got von Humelrich usz allen’, twice (lower left)
Other phrases are erased or otherwise difficult to read.
Marks of ownership (cf. Provenance) include: ‘Codex sanctorum martirum Marcellini et Petri in Selegunstadt’ (lower middle; written a few times above and below); ‘Edges’ (lower middle)

msItem.title: Homiliary
msItem.note: From Holy Saturday to the Octave of Pentecost (ending incomplete)

Major feast-days include Easter (fol. 6v), the Sunday after Easter (fol. 39v), the first Sunday after the octave of Easter (fol. 4v), Ascension (fol. 74v), and Pentecost (fol. 93r). The vigil of Pentecost starts on a new quire (after the short Quire 11), and is written by a different scribe.

Mostly from the Homiliary of Paul the Deacon, but with additional homilies for Pentecost week including two from the so-called 'Bavarian homiliary', for which see H. Barré, Les homéliaires carolingiens de l'école d'Auxerre: authenticité, inventaire, tableaux comparatifs (Vatican, 1962), 26 and tables. References to Paul the Deacon are to the homilies as numbered in R. Gregoire, Homéliaires liturgiques médiévaux: analyse de manuscrits, 423-78, with numbers in parentheses referring to the collection as described in PL 95.

msItem.author: Rabanus Maurus
msItem.title: Hom. LX
msItem.rubric: Feria IIa. Secundum Iohannem. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Dixit Iesus discipulis suis, Sic enim deus
Notandum quod dominus eadem de filio dei unigenito replicat
msItem.explicit: Currite dum lucem habetis ne tenebre uos comprehendant

msItem.author: Rabanus Maurus
msItem.title: Hom. LXII
msItem.rubric: Feria IIIa. Secundum Johannem. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Dixit Iesus discipulis suis, Amen Amen dico uobis qui non intrat
Hoc per uerbumprouerbium dicit eis Iesus. Illi autem non cognouerunt quid loqueretur eis. Propter Phariseorum
msItem.explicit: sed cum ipso pastore uiuant in eterna beatitudine et regnent per omnia secula seculorum Amen

msItem.author: Augustine
msItem.title: Tract. in Iohannem XXVI
msItem.rubric: Feria IIII. Secundum Johannem. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Dixit Iesus discipulis suis, Ego sum panis
msItem.rubric: Omelia Augustini episopi
msItem.incipit: Cum dominus noster Iesus Christus sicut in euangelio cum legeretur audiuimus panem se esse dixisset
msItem.explicit: moriuntur qui Christum manducant sed uiuunt in ęternum quia Christus uita ęterna est

msItem.rubric: Feria V secundum Lucam. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Conuocatis Iesus duodecim
msItem.rubric: Omelia venerabilis Bede presbiteri
msItem.incipit: Modo frates cum euangelium legeretur audiuimus quia conuocatis Iesus duodecim apostolis dedit illis uirtutem et potestatem super omnia demonia et ut languores curarent. Et misit illos predicare regnum dei et sanare infirmos. Fortasse enim nemo crederet hominibus illitteratis
msItem.explicit: nos uicium gule abscidamus a nobis adiuuante deo uero et uiuo qui uiuit

msItem.author: Ambrose
msItem.title: Expositio in Lucam, V.10-15
msItem.rubric: Feria VIa secundum Lucam. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Factum est in una dierum et Iesus sedebat
msItem.rubric: Ambrosii episcopi
msItem.incipit: Et ecce viri portantes in lecto hominem
msItem.explicit: aliosquoque eorum lepra contaminet
msItem.bibl: ed. Gabriel Tissot, Sources chrétiennes (1956-8), I.186-8

msItem.rubric: Sabbato. Secundum Lucam. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Surgens Iesus de synagoga
msItem.rubric: Omelia beati Ambrosii
msItem.incipit: Cum intravit in domum Petri ut audistis ex lectione euangelica fratres karissimi socrus Petri tenebatur magnis febribus. Domus Petri quod dicitur vetus lex intelligitur
msItem.explicit: pax uera quę iam nobis non relinquitur sed datur, per dominum nostrum Iesum Christum qui uiuit

msItem.author: Bede
msItem.title: Homiliae euangelii II.18 (II.xii)
msItem.rubric: In octava Pentecostes. Secundum Iohannem. In illo tempore.
msItem.incipit: Erat homo ex phariseis
msItem.rubric: Omelia venerabilis Bede presbiteri de eadem lectione
msItem.incipit: Sicut ex lectione sancti euangelii fratres karissimi audistis princeps Iudeorum uenit ad dominum nocte
msItem.explicit: subiungit uero de terrenis et sicut Moyses exalta
msItem.bibl: CCSL 122.311-7; PL 94.197-202; Paul the Deacon 16 (In Pascha annotina)

physDesc.p: Two codicological units (production units), fols. 1-86 and fol. 87-110

supportDesc.support: parchment; with occasional original holes and other flaws; one or more of the outer margins often excised
supportDesc.collation: 1–9(8), 10(8-1) (fols. 73–79, 6th leaf missing before fol. 78 but with no loss of text), 11(8–1) (fols. 80–86; last presumably blank cancelled) | 12–14(8); late(?)-medieval quire signatures in Roman numerals [i]– xiiij; ‘ix’ is used for both the 9th and 10th quires (fols. 72v, 79v, where corrected to ‘ixi’), but the 11th is correctly signed ‘xi’; ‘xiij’ occurs twice on one page (fol. 102v).

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet for two columns of 31 lines.

handDesc.handNote: Written mainly by two formal Romanesque bookhands, changing at the start of Quire 12.

decoDesc.decoNote: One historiated initial in red ink and green wash: St Matthew(?): a full-length standing male numbed figure, beardless but with long hair; he stands on top of a large foliate initial ‘U’ (fol. 1v).

Most of the major decoration occurs in the second part of the volume: One pair of large initials in red with a pale yellow wash background (fol. 87r); other major initials at the vigil of Pentecost (fol. 87r), and Pentecost (fols. 91v, 93v, 95v), the latter with a dragon-bird-vegetal hybrid. One foliate initial is sketched but not inked (fol. 6v); some spaces completely blank or with very faint designs sketched (e.g fol. 10r).
Doodles include human and animal/demon faces and figures, black-letter letters in outline, etc. (fol. 1r)

binding.p: Laudian binding. Sewn on four bands laced into pasteboards covered with brown leather, the centre of each cover stamped in gilt with the arms of archbishop Laud; no pastedowns; fore-edge tabs made partly from reused MS. waste (see e.g. fol. 2v); modern flyleaves; the joints repaired; traces of two ties at the fore-edge; the spine with vestiges of paper labels.

physDesc.accMat: The Summary Catalogue records the presence of ‘a fragment of a Latin Antiphoner of German origin’ which ‘may be 14th c.’, not mentioned in the Laud catalogue, and now absent.

history.provenance: Seligenstadt (diocese of Mainz), Benedictine abbey of Sts Marcellinus and Peter: inscribed in the 13th(?) century, ‘Codex sanctorum martirum Marcellini et Petri in Selegunstadt’(?) (fol. 1r, several times), and ‘Codex sanctorum mart..(?)’ (fol. 49r, upper margin).

The excision of margins happened by the 15th(?) century, to judge by the attempts to restore missing letters and words (e.g. fols. 20r, 26v, 65r–v); a 14th(?)-century hand added notes next to some texts which lack adequate rubrics, e.g. ‘de resurrectione domini’ (fol. 7v), and ‘in choro’ (fol. 106r).

Presumably in a Cistercian or Carthusian house when punctus elevatus punctuation was altered to punctus flexus punctuation (e.g. fol. 9r–v). The Summary Catalogue suggested that the 15th(?)-century shelfmark(?) (fol. 1v) in the form of a ‘U’ flanked on each side by squiggles shaped like a ‘z’ or medieval arabic numeral ‘2’, themselves flanked on each side by a dot: ‘.z. U .z.’, was comparable to a shelfmark(?) in MS. Laud Misc. 456, from the Mainz Charterhouse. The comparison is not convincing and there is no other evidence for Mainz provenance.
‘Edges’ written in a 16th- or early 17th-century English(?) hand (fols. 1r, 2r, lower margin).
Archbishop William Laud, 1573–1645: with the usual inscription, here dated 1638 (fol. 1v, lower margin).
history.acquisition: Part of his third donation to the Bodleian, 1639. Former Bodleian shelfmarks: ‘F.110’ (crossed through) and ‘Laud 465’ (encircled) (inside front cover).

recordHist.source: Description (May 2021) by Peter Kidd, edited by Matthew Holford. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (H. O. Coxe, Laudian Manuscripts, Quarto Catalogues II, repr. with corrections, 1969, from the original ed. of 1858–1885). Quarto Catalogue, cols. 339–40 Quarto Catalogue, p. 563 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 49

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project

listBibl.bibl: Otto Pächt and J. J. G. Alexander, Illuminated Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library, Oxford, I (1966), no. 72

revisionDesc.change: Description fully revised for Polonsky German digitization project.
